page.title: 10Cider Fruit Farming
page.content: Cider Fruit Farming Although a cider-producing county most farms have grubbed out their cider orchards as the older varieties are no longer acceptable to the manufacturers and an uneconomic crop. Bulmers own many orchards tending to take less from small growers. One local farm has 3 acres and produces 200 gallons of their own cider and perry from a 200 year old press. Another has 6 acres of fruit with varieties such as Dabinet, Norman, Michelin, Yarlington Mill and Tremelet. Harvesting can take up to 6 weeks and the fruit is transported by the farmer with no guaranteed prices or quotas at the selling end. Many of the old varieties (often more tasteful) are now lost except for the cultivars held in research stations, or gene banks.
